title: What are the qualifications needed to be a genetic counselor? - Quora

response.answer_text: Genetic counselors have a Master’s in Genetic Counseling from an ACGC (Accreditation Council for Genetic Counseling) Accredited Program. There are currently 32 programs in the United States and 3 in Canada. After completing the degree requirements, graduates are eligible to sit for a certification exam and pursue licensure in their state. Not all states have license requirements, but you can find a list of those that do here.  The path to getting into the graduate programs involves at minimum: Undergraduate degree and prerequisite courses - the exact list varies between programs but it's usually some combination of genetics courses, statistics, cell biology, chemistry, organic chemistry, biochemistry, psychology, counseling, human development, etc.Experiences in genetic counseling - often volunteer or shadowing experiences are sufficientAdvocacy or crisis counseling experienceThese 2-year graduate programs include:  Coursework in advanced medical genetics, biochemistry, cyto/molecular genetics, embryology, cancer genetics, variant interpretation, research methods and counseling.Clinical rotations and a number of documented cases in the typical clinical settings are required: prenatal, cancer, and pediatrics.Some type of original research project and/or thesis depending on program requirements.
